channel.title: Healthy Child Care
channel.description: Updated Healthy Child Care content from the US Environmental Protection Agency

item.title: Healthy Child Care: Trainings and Webinars for Government Agencies
item.description:
Trainings and webinars:

  • Creating Healthy Indoor Environments in Child Care Settings (PDF)(46 pp, 4 MB)
  • Green Cleaning, Sanitizing, and Disinfecting: A Toolkit for Early Care and Education (PDF)(74 pp, 5 MB)
  • Integrated Pest Management in Child Care Centers: Protecting our Children from Pests and Pesticides (PDF)(99 pp, 20 MB)
  • Small Steps to Improve Children's Environmental Health in Your Early Childhood Program: Common Practices to Keep Your Kids Safer (PDF)(18 pp, 2 MB)
  • Lead (presentation from the Children's Environmental Health Network) (PDF)(21 pp, 1 MB)
  • Protecting Children's Environmental Health in Child Care Settings: Children's Creative Learning Center's Policies and Practices (PDF)(6 pp, 113 K)
item.dc:creator: cdibbl03

item.title: Information for Government Agencies about Siting Child Care Facilities
item.description:
Young children are at greater risk than adults from exposure to environmental contaminants.  However, most child care centers are not required to conduct an environmental site assessment prior to obtaining a license.  Such assessments could help prevent child care centers from operating on sites that could expose children to harmful pollution from neighboring industrial facilities or contamination from past industrial use.  This section of the website provides resources to help you identify sources of pollution near your facility.

Resources

  • Child Day Care SAFER Program Exit
  • Environmental Guidance for All Child Care Facilities & Educational Facilities Exit
  • New York Daycare Center Licensing Requirements Exit
item.dc:creator: rwashing

item.title: Green Cleaning, Sanitizing, and Disinfecting: A Toolkit for Early Care and Education
item.description:
Toolkit for early child care and education discussing green cleaning, sanitizing, and disinfecting.

  • A Checklist for Early Care and Education (PDF)(12 pp, 597 K)
  • Breaking the Chain of Infection in Early Care and Education (PDF)(1 pg, 3 MB)
  • Fact Sheet: Hand Washing (PDF)(2 pp, 1 MB)
  • Fact Sheet: How to Properly Label a Cleaning Product Container (PDF)(2 pp, 301 K)
  • Fact Sheet: Non-chemical Ways to Reduce the Spread of Infectious Disease (PDF)(2 pp, 779 K)
  • Fact Sheet: What's So Great About Microfiber? (PDF)(2 pp, 2 MB)
item.dc:creator: lswitzer

item.title: Information for Government Agencies about Drinking Water in Child-Care Settings
item.description:
Young children are at particular risk for exposure to contaminants in drinking water because, pound for pound, they drink more water than adults (including water used to prepare formula), and because their immature body systems are less efficient at detoxification. Exposure to lead in drinking water is a serious health concern, especially for young children and infants since elevated lead levels in children may result in delays in physical or mental development, lower IQ , and even brain damage.

To assist child care centers with implementation of programs and policies to reduce exposure to contaminants, such as lead in drinking water, EPA uses the 3Ts concept: Training, Testing, Telling. The tools in this section provide information on the steps that can be taken to reduce such exposures.

Resources

  • Drinking Water Best Management Practices for Schools and Child Care Facilities Served By Municipal Water Systems(18 pp, 1 MB, About PDF) 
  • Drinking Water Best Management Practices for Schools and Child Care Facilities With Their Own Drinking Water Source(22 pp, 1 MB, About PDF)
item.dc:creator: Anonymous

To assist child care centers with implementation of programs and policies to reduce exposure to contaminants, such as lead in drinking water, EPA uses the 3Ts concept: Training, Testing, Telling. The tools in this section provide information on the steps that can be taken to reduce such exposures.

item.dc:creator: rwashing

item.title: Information for Government Agencies about Green Cleaning in Child-Care Settings
item.description:
Green cleaning refers to the use of cleaning products that have a reduced impact on human health and the environment, often because they have been re-formulated to eliminate the most potentially toxic ingredients. Child care providers recognize the important role that cleaning, sanitizing, and disinfecting can have in maintaining an attractive, safe, hygienic environment and reducing the spread of germs. But, it is important to know when cleaning is good enough and when sanitization or disinfection, which may involve harsher chemicals, is called for.

And, given the growing set of state requirements promoting green cleaning in early learning environments and schools and increased availability of green cleaning products, it is important for child care providers to know how to identify and use green cleaning products. The following links provide information about the dangers of cleaning products and the steps that can be taken to utilize less toxic alternatives in a childcare setting.

Resources

  • Green Cleaning, Sanitizing, and Disinfecting: A Curriculum for Early Care and Education
  • Important Information About New Bleach Concentration Exit
item.dc:creator: cdibbl03
